basics.name: Xiaocan Li (李晓璨)
basics.position: Staff Scientist, T-2, Los Alamos National Laboratory
basics.summary: Plasma physicist investigating particle acceleration, transport, and energy conversion in solar, space, and astrophysical plasmas through multi-scale kinetic, MHD, and transport simulations.

work.name: T-2, Los Alamos National Laboratory
work.summary: Lead research on particle acceleration and transport in space, solar, and astrophysical plasmas using multi-scale kinetic and MHD simulations.
highlights: Develop GPU-accelerated transport solvers that bridge kinetic and global MHD calculations on LANL and DOE supercomputers.
Coordinate multi-institutional efforts that connect numerical predictions with solar observations and laboratory experiments.

work.name: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Dartmouth College
work.summary: Coupled PIC, MHD, and transport simulations to interpret particle energization signatures in solar eruptions.
highlights: Linked reconnection-driven acceleration models with X-ray and microwave observations to explain nonthermal emissions.
Mentored graduate and undergraduate students on reconnection-rate scaling, magnetotail reconnection, and simulation workflows.

work.name: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Dartmouth College
work.summary: Investigated reconnection-rate reduction in high-beta plasmas and power-law formation in relativistic regimes.
highlights: Integrated transport-solvers with MHD outputs to study solar-flare acceleration and energetic particle propagation.
Executed large-scale PIC simulations that quantified reconnection dynamics and particle energization.

work.name: T-2, Los Alamos National Laboratory
work.summary: Analyzed particle acceleration mechanisms in solar flare reconnection using VPIC simulations and transport models.
highlights: Coupled kinetic results with MHD simulations and observations to evaluate acceleration efficiencies.
Studied drift motions, pressure anisotropy, and field amplification in reconnection and shock environments.

work.name: CSPAR, The University of Alabama in Huntsville
work.summary: Modeled plasma-tether interactions using kinetic simulations.

work.name: Center for Space Plasma and Aeronomic Research, UAH
work.summary: Ph.D. research on numerical simulations of particle acceleration during solar flares.
highlights: Developed test-particle codes for chaotic magnetic fields and performed VPIC simulations of reconnection-driven acceleration.
Built Parker transport models to bridge kinetic simulations with solar observations.

work.name: T-2, Los Alamos National Laboratory
work.summary: Long-term research visits focused on reconnection energization and supernova remnant shocks.
highlights: Used VPIC to probe drift motions, shear/compression, and pressure anisotropy during reconnection.
Modeled magnetic-field amplification and cosmic-ray acceleration with coupled MHD and transport simulations.

work.name: Department of Geophysics, Peking University
work.summary: Modeled electron transport with Monte Carlo (Geant4) simulations during M.S. studies.

education.institution: The University of Alabama in Huntsville
